newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares fall, seen entering correction.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares fall, seen entering correction.

text.p: Polish shares fell for the second session running and analysts said Wednesday's higher turnover which accompanied the unexpected fall and strong selling after price fixing signalled they could enter a correction phase.

Some analysts said that despite earlier expectations of a possible testing the July 5 high of 14,282.2 of the WIG index, the market could fall to 13,000 points in profit-taking correction after the 11.6 percent rise since mid-August.
"Today's session shows that the market might enter a correction phase," said Ryszard Wojnowski, an analyst at Bank Gdanski brokerage.
The WIG fell 0.6 percent, to 13,882.3 and turnover rose 8.9 percent to 110.3 million zlotys on both markets as a total of 48 issues fell, 15 rose and 14 were flat.
Analysts said the correction was likely to be brief and that the market might rise again and challenge the July 5 high. But they were divided whether it would keep on rising afterwards or fall.
Analysts expected the bourse to be influenced next week by investors speculative trade ahead of releases of companies' August earnings reports, due in mid-September.
They were surprised by the garment maker Bytom's 10-percent surge in a 1.1-million zloty turnover.
Continuous trade turnover was at 0.8 million zlotys with BPH, the only stock trading, staying flat.
Mass privatisation NFI units rose 2.6 percent in a heavy 18.5-million zloty turnover in the single price auction system and rose 3.1 percent in a 2.1-million zloty continuous trade.
